[Mr Speaker in the Chair]

CONSTITUTIONAL TALKS IN
LONDON
(March 1957)


    The Chief Minister (Mr Lim Yew Hock): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have the Governor's consent to move, and I do now hereby move the motion standing in my name, namely,

    That this Assembly approves the recommendations of the All-Party Conference, as set out in Sessional Paper No. Misc. 1 of 1957, and on the principles therein set out instructs the All-Party Mission to secure from Her Majesty's Government for the people of Singapore the status of a self-governing state with all the rights, powers, and privileges thereto appurtenant in all internal affairs and the control of trade, commerce and cultural relations in external affairs.

    Sir, before I proceed any further, I would like to draw the attention of hon. Members to an error on page 3, paragraph 13 (c) , line 3 - the word "three" should read "two".

    Sir, the terms of the motion are clear. We are seeking complete internal self-government and not independence. We maintain and maintain with all vigor that the people of Singapore have the inalienable right to self-determination and to deny them this right will be tantamount to a breach of faith on the part of Her Majesty's Government. We want to remain friends with Britain, but our dignity as equals must be recognized. A new chapter in the relationship between Britain and ourselves is being written and this chapter can be a happy one of healthy and fruitful co-operation if the Mission succeeds.

    The other picture I hesitate to paint. But the hand that holds the brush is not, in Singapore but in London. The All-Party Mission to London is all set

Column: 1458

to leave tomorrow on its quest for a new Constitution for the people of Singapore. It seeks sustenance from the unanimous support of the people's representatives in this Assembly on the principles enunciated in the White Paper, which is its blueprint for a self-governing Singapore. The Members of the All-Party Mission are drawn from delegates to the All-Party Conference, and I take heart from the unity of purpose displayed in the conference that the All-Party Mission will be a united force fully conscious of the task before them and pledged to do their best for the people of Singapore. The unity of our voice in this Assembly on this national issue will provide the fuel with which the All-Party Mission will steer the ship, the "State of Singapore", safely into port. I do not wish to give the impression that all will be plain sailing. We are bound to encounter rough weather, but we will not flounder nor founder, for team-work will pull us through.

    Sir, I do not propose to go into detail on all the items in the White Paper, as most of them are self-explanatory and do not require elucidation. Moreover, the White Paper is the result of the labours of the All-Party Conference and ten Members of this Assembly have been closely associated in its deliberations. On page 2, paragraph 8, of the White Paper is the following sentence:

    "The conference's decision is that the All-Party Mission will not accept anything less than what had already been offered by the United Kingdom Government."

Sir, some uncharitable and uninformed people may think that we are going to accept what the last delegation had rejected. This is far from the truth. We are pressing for a Malayan Governor-General, which proposal had not been accepted by Her Majesty's Government during the last talks, and the matter was still being examined by Her Majesty's Government before the talks broke down. We do not propose to accept the Defense and Security Council offered by Her Majesty's Government, and the line that the Mission will take on this all-important issue is set out in paragraphs 9, 10 and 11 on page 3 of the White Paper. Apart from these two major issues, the

Column: 1459

other recommendations can be found on pages 3 and 4 of the White Paper.

    Paragraph 8, Sir, page 2, of the White Paper, gives details of Her Majesty's proposals during the last talks on which there had been no disagreement, and the line the Mission will take in London is that these proposals are accepted in principle and that the discussion should be confined to details only. Thus it can be seen that the blueprint of the All-Party Mission is an improvement on the offers of Her Majesty's Government during the last talks.

    Sir, on the Security Council proposed by us, the set-up includes a Minister from the Federation of Malaya with equal representation by the Singapore Government and Her Majesty's Government. This has been made possible by the fine co-operation of the Federation Chief Minister, Tunku Abdul Rahman, and I would like to express to him in this Assembly the thanks of the people of Singapore.

    Sir, at the bottom of page 2 of the White Paper, the following appears:

    "Proposal No. 23. Provision to be made for the creation of a Singapore citizenship on the lines of the proposal in paragraph 9 of the Heads of Agreement circulated by the Singapore Delegation (SCT. (56) 5)."

Sir, Her Majesty's Government had agreed in principle to the creation of a Singapore citizenship under a new State of Singapore. Whether the citizenship rights should come into force before the creation of the State of Singapore or after was a question that confronted the All-Party Conference. It was felt that the people affected should enjoy these rights and exercise their votes in the choice of a new Government for the State of Singapore. To achieve this, the conference fully realised that this would mean that it would be impossible for the general elections to take place in August this year to which the Government is committed. The British Nationality Act will require an amendment by the British Parliament. Citizenship laws will have to be introduced in Singapore. A reasonable length of time of, say, one year should be given to persons affected to make application if we really mean them to enjoy these rights. New electoral rolls will have to be prepared under

Column: 1460

the Legislative Assembly Elections Ordinance. All these take time. I told the All-Party Conference that I did not wish to influence them on this matter, as I did not wish it to be said that the Government was seeking a way out of its promise to hold elections in August this year. In view of the great importance of the matter, the All-Party Conference felt that the All-Party Mission should seek the views of this Assembly and be guided accordingly. I would therefore ask hon. Members to express their views to guide us on the line to take with the Colonial Office on our citizenship proposals. The Government does not intend to ignore its commitments, but is prepared to listen to the views and advice of hon. Members. I must explain the reason that prompted the Government to announce that it would hold elections in August this year under the new Constitution to be secured from Her Majesty's Government. Hon. Members will recollect that the Government took firm action against subversive elements last September and October. This imposed and is still imposing a great strain on my colleagues and me. This is a heavy responsibility, but we are not deterred by it. While we are in office, we mean to govern, and govern in the best interests of the people of Singapore. Under the circumstances, I felt that the Labour Front Coalition should face the electorate as soon as possible under the new constitution to ascertain whether the action the Government has taken has the support of the people of Singapore. In fact, the machinery has already been set in motion to prepare electoral rolls on the basis of the present franchise, and it had been in my mind that as soon as agreement had been reached in London, I would seek an immediate amendment to the Order in Council to give legality to the electoral rolls which would be awaiting publication. I find it imperative that I should say this now to protect the Government against any malicious charges that may be levied in the future should the views of this Assembly necessitate an enforced delay in holding the elections.

    The Government, Sir, is in favor of giving every opportunity to all persons

Column: 1461

who will acquire citizenship rights to have a say in the choice of a new government under the new Constitution. But in view of the Government's commitment to hold elections in August this year. the Government will abide by the views of hon. Members. If the consensus of view is for citizenship rights to be introduced ahead of the new Constitution, then the responsibility for delaying the general elections should rest with this Assembly, and the Government should not be blamed for postponing it. Under these circumstances, the date of coming into force of the new Constitution will have to be synchronized with the date of the general elections.

    Sir, the All-Party Conference considered the joint memorandum received by me from certain communal organizations, and came to the unanimous conclusion that the provision of specially reserved seats for sectional interests was not acceptable to our concept of a fully elected legislature under our constitutional proposals for a State of Singapore.

    An official invitation was received from the Secretary of State inviting Members of the Mission to be guests of Her Majesty's Government from the date of the Mission's arrival in the United Kingdom until the end of the conference. We are indeed very grateful to Her Majesty's Government for this hospitality, and I trust that while we are enjoying it, we will be able to drink from the cup of success.

    I do not propose to speak at great length, Sir, nor do I wish to take this opportunity to make a pre-election speech. The fight is not here but in London. I would therefore ask the Members of the Mission to conserve their energy, play their part well and strive to maintain that exhilarating unity which has been displayed by them in the All-Party Conference. Let our thoughts be calm and collected, and let us go with hope in our hearts and no ill words on our lips.

    In conclusion, Sir, I would like to quote some lines from the great Indian poet Tagore, which it seems to me define our sense of high endeavor in face

Column: 1462

of the next stage of our political development:

    Where the mind is without fear and the head is held high;

    Where knowledge is free;

    Where the world has not been broken into fragments by narrow domestic walls;

    Where words come out from the depths of truth;

    Where tireless striving stretches its arms towards perfection;

    Where the clear stream of reason has not lost its way in the dreary desert sand of dead habit;

    Where the mind is led forward by thee into ever-widening thought and action;

    Into that heaven of freedom, my Father, let my country awake!

10.22 a.m.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong (Serangoon): Mr Speaker, Sir, as a Member of the All-Party Conference, I rise to second the motion. In Singapore, at the last elections, we had had many people shouting about merdeka. I think that was a misnomer. All that we asked for during last year until now was just self-government. The people of Singapore of course want to govern themselves, to run their own affairs, to be an independent people, to be proud that they are able to handle what should be their own rights. Responsibility in this matter must be shown to the world at large, and the people of Singapore today have shown that.

    In the matter of independence or self-government, we must not only be able to do the cushy jobs in offices and do just the administrative part of it, but also must be able to rise to the occasion and to sacrifice our property and our lives if necessary, in the interests of the country. Today, the newspapers report that young men of Singapore are conscious of that. The registration of the Singapore Regiment is ample proof that the people of Singapore are ready to shoulder greater responsibility. They are enthusiastic in joining this new Singapore Regiment, which will be the nucleus of a band of people devoted to the country, and will lay down their lives if necessary to defend this country. This is solid proof to the world that we want self-government not only because it

Column: 1463

brings in the good things, but also we are able to defend ourselves and take on more of the onerous duties.

    The lines drawn up by the All-Party Conference and the demands that we are going to make in London are well known in Singapore. I think everybody has accepted them. We had more or less the same lines last year but we failed. We failed because of one thing - man had put self-interest first, party interest again in the fore, and national interests at the bottom. I think today all Members of every political party realize that the first interest must be national interest. We go today, Sir, as one unit with one aim, and that aim is that we will fight first and foremost and every time, for national interests. We will do away with party interests. That will come only after we have achieved our national aspirations, and I think we all realize that in a community like this, self should be put last.

    This year, I think we are going to London with some experience. We have before us the mistakes we committed last year, where one party shouted at another party, ridiculed another party, in a foreign land; so much so that our opposite numbers could pierce through our armor very easily, too easily, and we came back empty-handed. This time, we realize that mistake and I think we will not commit that same error again. We will bring back, as somebody said, the bacon to Singapore.

    The demands that we have are realistic. We know our limits. We know how far we can go and we demand just the minimum that we should have, and I think we will have that. We have the support of the people behind us solidly. Everyone in Singapore has come to realize that this is an important issue and that everyone in Singapore supports this Mission to the full. With the support of the people, the United Kingdom Government will realise that they are not dealing with a band of five people, but are dealing with a whole mass of 1,250,000 people in Singapore.

    However, I must say that whatever we ask for this time is only just one step

Column: 1464

forward. We are only asking for self-government. We are not asking for merdeka, but Singapore cannot stop at that. As the former Chief Minister said, we must grow up, we must make our mistakes, we must fall down, we must pick ourselves up and we must learn by the hard way, but I think we are taking every precaution not to fall and hurt ourselves so much that we end up in the mortuary. We will learn to walk, we will learn to run, but we will take every step to see that whatever we do, we grow from strength to strength.

    Our next step, of course, will be the real merdeka, as the word should signify, and we want it to be as soon as possible. Sir, you will realize that from the Sessional Paper No. Misc. 1 of 1957, we are going there to negotiate with the United Kingdom for self-government but, within a time limit of four years, we must go back again and negotiate for real independence. The time may come earlier. It may be just three years or two, and I know that as soon as we know our strength, as soon as we know that we are fully equipped for independence, we will go and ask for it. The people of Singapore must work towards this goal, and I know that it will be soon enough it all of us pull our weight together.

    There are, however, a few timid people in Singapore who are afraid of merdeka. They make representations, they voice their opinions in the newspapers and say that they do not want merdeka. These consist only of a very small section of the people. They are afraid to come out of their cosy holes. They are afraid that things might go wrong. But we have before us our great neighbor, India. She has come out and become an independent nation. She is today one of the leading nations in the world. Everything that is done there is peaceful and progressive, and we know that we certainly will follow that great brother through that road of independence and progress.

    The Chief Minister mentioned that the Government promised the people elections during August. We realize that it is not possible to have elections

Column: 1465

at that time if we are going to give the right of vote to the 200,000 people who are eligible to become Singapore citizens. This section of people forms a very important part of Singapore. They have contributed a great deal to the good of Singapore. They are as loyal to Singapore as the local-born. And these people should be given the vote. However, if we are going to achieve that, as the Chief Minister said, this takes time. We agree with him that this takes time, but we say that the time taken should be cut down to a minimum and that elections should be held at the earliest possible moment. Time must be budgetted so that these people have the vote, and that elections can be held as early as possible.

    Tomorrow we go to London with the unity of purpose and I know that we will succeed.

    Question proposed.

10.30 a.m.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to support the motion before this House. We all gave our consent to this motion. We all agreed with the White Paper now before the Assembly. I think the terms of the motion is an indication of the great difference this time from last time. I do not claim any credit for this particular resolution, in fact I had very little to do with it. But I did look up the former resolution. The House will forgive me if I were to remind them of the terms of the resolution they passed on the 5th April last year. The resolution first opens with a flourish by a reference to the Washington Declaration of Dwight D. Eisenhower, it said:

    "That this Assembly, affirms in the name of the people of Singapore, its belief in the principle of 'the basic right of peoples to governments of their own choice', as enunciated in the Washington Declaration signed by Sir Anthony Eden, Prime Minister of the United Kingdom" (now politically deceased) "and President Eisenhower, President of the United States of America, on the 1st of February, 1956",

Column: 1466

and so on, and winds up by saying:

    ". . . to seek forthwith for Singapore the status of an independent territory within the Commonwealth, and to offer" (mark you the word, Mr Speaker, 'offer') "an agreement and the Singapore Government of the United Kingdom would in respect of Singapore exercise control over external defence and give guidance in foreign relations other than trade and commerce."

    Those were fierce words and, I am sorry to say, they did not materialize. Looking back now, I thought - like when the platform collapsed at the famous rally at Kallang - it was a symbolic act of unwisdom of people who did not prepare the ground before they climbed on the platform.

    However, that is all past history. We go again this time, as the Member for Serangoon has said, with more experience. He will not this time be so befuddled by the London traffic, nor by the habits of the people of London. Like other members of the former delegation had they returned, he would have gone back as a connoisseur of London café life. But the Member for Serangoon is the one man who, although we very often disagree with his political views, we respect for the sincerity with which he holds them.

    This merdeka conference has been so completely quiet and different from the last. There is no warming up as there was the last time. My Party thought that we should at least have one rally before we depart. And in case we are accused of wanting to demonstrate our own strength and mass support, we suggested that we should hold an all-party rally. But the consternation with which this suggestion was received led us to the conclusion that perhaps, for the sake of all-party unity, we should depart with as little noise as possible. I hope this time, though, when we return with or without success, we shall return with a bang and not with a damp squib of a noise with which the last mission returned.

    I think it is no secret that we have not only reached agreement to ask for what we have stated in the White Paper in

Column: 1467

clear and precise terms, namely, no more than complete internal self-government. It is also no secret that we have reached agreement to take united action if the talks should fail. But I do not think that the chances of failure are high. This London Conference will be an anti-climax after the last one. This time, we go there with our demands more clearly defined and soberly, but firmly pressed. Last time there was some uncertainty as to what exactly we were asking for. There were occasions when I heard it mooted that we should join the United Nations because if we get independence and then we give back certain powers and privileges connected with defense and foreign relations, we should be eligible to join the United Nations. I am glad that this time all parties agree that what we are asking for is no more than complete internal self-government, and we are telling the people of Singapore so before we leave so that no one can say that we have not put the facts before them.

    My Party's stand on this matter is quite clear. My Party says if we want independence we must get merger with the Federation. This is as far as we can go until merger. The next is merger.

    I said that I believe the coming talks will succeed. I give these following reasons for it: three from the Singapore point of view and the same three from the British point of view. First from the Singapore point of view, our clearly defined demands present to the British something which guarantees their paramount military and strategic needs, and, at the same time give us adequate room for full internal control. Second, there is more sense of cohesion in the All-Party Conference and, I hope, in the delegation. Also, this conference will be led by someone less emotional and flamboyant than our last leader. I am not saying that emotion and flamboyance have not played in the development of nations. But we discovered from the last conference that they were not necessarily the qualities which brought success at the conference table. The third reason is that the British Government knows that if this time it fails, we are agreed on united action when we return.

Column: 1468



    These three reasons looked at from the British point of view mean, first, that the British have now a better appraisal of how much less than full independence she is giving away. Second, they have a better appraisal of the position of the Federation Minister in the defence known as the Security Council in the ratio of three, three, one. It may well be that as Mr Lennox-Boyd indicated at the last talks some arrangements may have been reached between Her Majesty's Government and the Federation Government in their defence treaty about the member from the Federation who will sit on this Security Council of Singapore. But whatever the inner workings of the defence treaty, it is clear that the British Government finds it now palatable, when it was not last year. Thirdly, the same third reason looked at from the British point of view is that last time all that happened was we changed Chief Ministers. This time it is not likely that the Labour Front Coalition Government will survive a defeat of these talks. The Hon. the Chief Minister will remember that he has promised to resign if these talks fail. Try how one will, I do not see how, out of this Assembly of 32 persons; one could form another Government if this Government resigns. Consequently, I consider we have more chances of success than we had the last time. I personally anticipate some difficulty on two matters: one, the question of the expatriate judges and their tenure of office; two, the position of the Governor-General. We do not want to cross our bridges before we come to them. The stand of the All-Party delegation is quite clear and it is in the White Paper. We intend to have our own Judiciary as soon as possible. We intend to have the power to remove judges who have been appointed by the Colonial Legal Service as and when we have the men who can fill their roles. The fight over the Governor-General has become so acute since the U.M.N.O.'s demand as to who should be the first Governor-General that I do not think anybody now would want to let that plum go.

Column: 1469



    However, we are glad that, in spite of all our trials and tribulations, and threats of desertions from the All-Party Conference, we have settled our differences and we hope to go to London as an effective unit. The question which must more engage the minds of the people of Singapore is what happens after the conference if it succeeds. There are two phases of what happens after a successful conference. The immediate one will open with the new elections under the new constitution. The long-term one is where we go to from now to get freedom

    Sir, I had never believed that there were going to be elections in August. When I heard the Member for Cairnhill (Mr D. S. Marshall) chasing like a terrier after his former Labour Minister to pin him down to a date for elections, I knew that the promise of elections by August was not one which could be fulfilled unless one dropped the citizenship proposals. We were silent then because we wanted to know to what extent internal contradictions within the Labour Front could wreck the Government of the Labour Front. We watched with considerable interest the developments of these internal contradictions and we are sorry today that the Member for Cairnhill is not here to give us his blessings. We were the first to ask for elections - in fact, we asked the Government to face an election at a time when the Government thought it was ungentlemanly to ask it to do so. Once elections were not held then, any student of the Singapore political scene could have added two and two together to say that there would be no elections in 1957 because one cannot get a new constitution and prepare new electoral registers by 1957 unless, as the Hon. the Chief Minister has put it, we use the old electoral registers. That is a suggestion which is bound to be unpalatable and bound to create the greatest consternation and opposition from so many quarters that have long agitated for citizenship. The decision of my Party is that the reputed 200,000 people who would have the right to vote under the new citizenship laws should be put on the register before the next elections. Sir,

Column: 1470

the length of time required to allow them to register and to prepare the new electoral rolls is a matter which requires more consideration. The Chief Minister has mentioned the period of one year for registration for citizenship, which means, in effect, one year plus a period of at least three further months for the preparation of the registers. I do not think that we have carefully considered all aspects of this administrative problem. I would leave my Party free on the question of the length of time for the time being. We will have to discuss this matter more carefully to see whether it can be done more expeditiously and more quickly. But, on principle, we agree that they should be on the register.

    The next election is bound to be more far-reaching in consequences. It may wreck the present Government as the last elections did the Progressive Party, because two important alterations to conditions of the political arena have been agreed to, namely, multilingualism and Singapore citizenship. But whatever Government is elected into power in the next elections under the new constitution, it faces two important limitations. First, any policy it carries out which brings on the rancor of the Federation Government can be countered by economic sanctions by the Federation Government. We all know what has happened to the attempts of the Minister for Commerce and Industry to get the tax on soap and biscuits lifted. That is just the beginning of new trends which are bound to emerge as the two Governments become more and more distinct in their outlook and their political identities. No Singapore Government can carry out a fiscal policy which conflicts with that of the Federation without strong economic sanctions being imposed. It is impossible to carry out a revolutionary Socialist programme in Singapore if the Federation Government is of the opinion that that is bad for the Federation and it does not wish to pursue a similar programme there.

    The second limitation which may not be so immediate but is nonetheless real is the political sanction under the constitution - suspension; and there will be enough British military forces in the

Column: 1471

country to make suspension of the constitution a practical proposition. The consequences of a suspension may be far-reaching but any Government in power at the next elections would be dishonest if it did not tell the people beforehand that it will have, although there is complete internal freedom, those two limitations on its independence of action within Singapore itself.

    With this new constitution, we come to the end of one phase of the fight for freedom. The Member for Serangoon (Mr Lim Choon Mong) said that we should prepare and fight on for merdeka but he did not mention how. Presumably, one day when all the people of Singapore have decided that they want merdeka, not internal self-government, we will all shout for merdeka and we will send another All-Party delegation. In the context of the second half of the 20th century South-East Asia, island nations are political jokes. If we want to get freedom, there is no other way out. Let us face the fact that we must make it palatable to the Federation to help us in order to help itself. That is the second phase after the expected successful conclusion of the next talks.

    We all know that the Tunku and perhaps a number of his colleagues are against merger in no uncertain terms, and they have repeatedly said so. I sincerely believe that they are misguided in believing that separation is the lesser of two evils. It is not said by the Federation Government that merger is bad itself. All they say is that because of certain consequences of merger, they would rather not have one. Sir, the Tunku said that for as long as he is Chief Minister there would be no merger. So unless he changes his mind, it appears to us that we will have to wait till we have a new Chief Minister or perhaps a new Prime Minister. But without wishing to say any thing about the internal politics of the Federation, I would hate to believe that the leaders of the political Parties in the Federation are unable to see that it is better to have Singapore as part of the Federation and under Federation control than outside the Federation and outside its political

Column: 1472

or military control. For the only control the Federation can have over Singapore is, as I have mentioned, an indirect economic one. A Singapore Government which is prepared to run economic hazards can embarrass the Federation Government no end. In fact on one occasion the Tunku said that, if necessary, he would send troops to occupy Singapore. I think I am right in my recollection that he would send troops, if necessary. Sir, would it not be better to have us as part of the Federation under the control of the Federation without having the necessity to send troops to invade and conquer? We are offering to go into the Federation and we still should offer to go in as a unitary state in the Federation which means that no balance of power in the Federation would be radically upset. I am convinced that whatever happens to the personalities involved in the leadership, the leadership itself must come to realize that the new Federation cannot depend upon the British to keep Singapore under control to prevent it from being an embarrassment to the Federation. So long as the British have troops here and can use those troops effectively, Singapore can, militarily, from the point of view of the shooting war in the Federation, be kept under control and in line with the Federation's tactics and methods. But these leaders must understand that the nationalist feeling in the Federation and the political consciousness of their people of the evils of colonialism are bound to rise more and more to make the Federation more like Egypt than Persia. Muslim countries like Jordan with a King as its head have already written off the British army together with General Gluhb Pasha. We are confident that the leaders of the Federation will understand this, if not now, in the not too distant future.
